content:
CollectionView Class

Definition

Represents a view for grouping, sorting, filtering, and navigating a data collection.

In this Article

public class CollectionView : System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherObject, System.Collections.IEnumerable, System.Collections.Specialized.INotifyCollectionChanged, System.ComponentModel.ICollectionView, System.ComponentModel.INotifyPropertyChanged
Inheritance
Object
System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherObject
CollectionView

Inherited Members

Equals(Object)
Equals(Object,Object)
GetHashCode()
GetType()
MemberwiseClone()
ReferenceEquals(Object,Object)
ToString()
CheckAccess()
Dispatcher
VerifyAccess()

Remarks

You should not create objects of this class in your code. To create a collection view for a collection that only implements IEnumerable, create a CollectionViewSource object, add your collection to the Source property, and get the collection view from the View property.

You can think of a collection view as a layer on top of a binding source collection that allows you to navigate and display the collection based on sort, filter, and group queries, all without having to manipulate the underlying source collection itself. If the source collection implements the INotifyCollectionChanged interface, the changes that raise the CollectionChanged event are propagated to the views.

Because a view does not change the underlying source collection, a source collection can have multiple views associated with it. By using views, you can display the same data in different ways. For example, you can use two views on a collection of Task objects to show tasks sorted by priority on one part of the page and grouped by area on another part of the page.

In WPF applications, all collections have an associated default collection view. Rather than working with the collection directly, the binding engine always accesses the collection through the associated view. To get the default view, use the GetDefaultView method. An internal class based on CollectionView is the default view for collections that implement only IEnumerable. ListCollectionView is the default view for collections that implement IList. BindingListCollectionView is the default view for collections that implement IBindingListView or IBindingList.

Alternatively, you can create a view of your collection in Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML) by using the CollectionViewSource class and then bind your control to that view. The CollectionViewSource class is the XAML representation of the CollectionView class. For an example, see How to: Sort and Group Data Using a View in XAML.

For more information, see "Binding to Collections" in Data Binding Overview.

To set a view in XAML, use the CollectionViewSource class. CollectionViewSource is the XAML representation of the CollectionView class, and it exposes the most commonly used members of the CollectionView class.

XAML Text Usage

See Remarks

Constructors

CollectionView(IEnumerable)

Initializes a new instance of the CollectionView class that represents a view of the specified collection.

public CollectionView (System.Collections.IEnumerable collection);
collection
IEnumerable

The underlying collection.

Remarks

The instance of CollectionView is bound to the user interface (UI) thread dispatcher of the caller of this constructor.

Properties

AllowsCrossThreadChanges

Gets a value that indicates whether a thread other than the one that created the CollectionView can change the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.SourceCollection*.

protected bool AllowsCrossThreadChanges { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if a thread other than the one that created the CollectionView can change the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.SourceCollection*; otherwise, false.

CanFilter

Gets a value that indicates whether the view supports filtering.

public virtual bool CanFilter { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if the view supports filtering; otherwise, false. The default is true.

Remarks

If this property returns false, setting the Filter property throws an exception.

CanGroup

Gets a value that indicates whether the view supports grouping.

public virtual bool CanGroup { get; }
Value
Boolean

false in all cases.

Remarks

Use this property to test whether the view supports sorting before adding GroupDescriptions. Derived classes override this property to indicate whether they support grouping.

CanSort

Gets a value that indicates whether the view supports sorting.

public virtual bool CanSort { get; }
Value
Boolean

false in all cases.

Remarks

Use this property to test whether the view supports sorting before adding SortDescriptions. Derived classes override this property to indicate whether they support sorting.

Comparer

Returns an object that you can use to compare items in the view.

public virtual System.Collections.IComparer Comparer { get; }
Value
IComparer

An IComparer object that you can use to compare items in the view.

Count

Gets the number of records in the view.

public virtual int Count { get; }
Value
Int32

The number of records in the view, or –1 if the number of records is unknown.

Remarks

If a filter is set, this property value only includes items that pass the filter. If the underlying collection is of type IEnumerable, this is an O(N) operation. This value is cached until the collection changes.

Culture

Gets or sets the culture information to use during sorting.

public virtual System.Globalization.CultureInfo Culture { get; set; }
Value
CultureInfo

The culture information to use during sorting.

CurrentItem

Gets the current item in the view.

public virtual object CurrentItem { get; }
Value
Object

The current item of the view. By default, the first item of the collection starts as the current item.

Remarks

Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer. As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection.

Note that moving the current record pointer has some interactions with any sorting or filtering that is applied to the collection. Sorting preserves the current record pointer on the last record selected, but the collection view is restructured around it. (Perhaps the selected record was at the beginning of the list before, but now the selected record might be somewhere in the middle.) Filtering preserves the selected record if that selection remains in view after the filtering. Otherwise, the current record pointer is set to the first record of the filtered collection view.

The current item of the collection is bound to automatically if the target of a binding is a singleton value. If the target is an ItemsControl, the current item is synchronized with the selected item. For example, if a list box is bound to a collection, the CurrentItem is synchronized with the currently selected item.

CurrentPosition

Gets the ordinal position of the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* within the (optionally sorted and filtered) view.

public virtual int CurrentPosition { get; }
Value
Int32

The ordinal position of the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* within the (optionally sorted and filtered) view.

Filter

Gets or sets a method used to determine if an item is suitable for inclusion in the view.

public virtual Predicate<object> Filter { get; set; }
Value
Predicate<Object>

A delegate that represents the method used to determine if an item is suitable for inclusion in the view.

Exceptions
NotSupportedException

The current implementation does not support filtering.

Remarks

Simpler implementations do not support filtering and throw a NotSupportedException. Use the CanFilter property to test if filtering is supported before assigning this property with a non-null value.

GroupDescriptions

Gets a collection of GroupDescription objects that describes how the items in the collection are grouped in the view.

public virtual System.Collections.ObjectModel.ObservableCollection<System.ComponentModel.GroupDescription> GroupDescriptions { get; }
Value
ObservableCollection<GroupDescription>

null in all cases.

Remarks

The value of this property is always null because the CollectionView class does not support grouping over its underlying collection. The derived classes ListCollectionView and BindingListCollectionView do support grouping.

Groups

Gets a collection of the top-level groups that is constructed based on the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.GroupDescriptions* property.

public virtual System.Collections.ObjectModel.ReadOnlyObservableCollection<object> Groups { get; }
Value
ReadOnlyObservableCollection<Object>

null in all cases.

Remarks

The value of this property is always null because the CollectionView class does not support grouping over its underlying collection. The derived classes ListCollectionView and BindingListCollectionView do support grouping.

IsCurrentAfterLast

Gets a value that indicates whether the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* of the view is beyond the end of the collection.

public virtual bool IsCurrentAfterLast { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* of the view is beyond the end of the collection; otherwise, false.

Remarks

Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer. As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection.

IsCurrentBeforeFirst

Gets a value that indicates whether the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* of the view is before the beginning of the collection.

public virtual bool IsCurrentBeforeFirst { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* of the view is before the beginning of the collection; otherwise, false.

Remarks

Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer. As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection.

IsCurrentInSync

Gets a value that indicates whether the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* is at the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentPosition*.

protected bool IsCurrentInSync { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* is in the view and at the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentPosition*; otherwise, false.

IsDynamic

Gets a value that indicates whether the underlying collection provides change notifications.

protected bool IsDynamic { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if the underlying collection provides change notifications; otherwise, false.

IsEmpty

Gets a value that indicates whether the resulting (filtered) view is empty.

public virtual bool IsEmpty { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if the resulting view is empty; otherwise, false.

IsInUse

Gets a value that indicates whether any object is subscribing to the events of this CollectionView.

public virtual bool IsInUse { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if any object is subscribing to the events of this CollectionView; otherwise, false.

IsRefreshDeferred

Gets a value that indicates whether there is an outstanding stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.DeferRefresh* in use.

protected bool IsRefreshDeferred { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if there is an outstanding stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.DeferRefresh* in use; otherwise, false.

NeedsRefresh

Gets a value that indicates whether the view needs to be refreshed.

public virtual bool NeedsRefresh { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if the view needs to be refreshed; otherwise, false.

Remarks

This property indicates if the internal state of the view has changed and requires a Refresh method call. The typical scenario is if a SortDescription or similar has been added to the view while the view is in a deferred refresh cycle (see DeferRefresh). In this scenario, no explicit call to Refresh is needed; as soon as the deferred refresh cycle ends, the view calls refresh automatically.

NewItemPlaceholder

Gets the object that is in the collection to represent a new item.

public static object NewItemPlaceholder { get; }
Value
Object

The object that is in the collection to represent a new item.

Remarks

When a CollectionView that implements IEditableCollectionView has NewItemPlaceholderPosition set to NewItemPlaceholderPosition or NewItemPlaceholderPosition, the NewItemPlaceholder is added to the collection. The NewItemPlaceholder always appears in the collection; it does not participate in grouping, sorting, or filtering.

The CurrentItem cannot be the NewItemPlaceholder. Methods that perform relative navigation, such as the MoveCurrentToNext, skip the NewItemPlaceholder. MoveCurrentToFirst and MoveCurrentToLast skip the NewItemPlaceholder if NewItemPlaceholderPosition is set to NewItemPlaceholderPosition or NewItemPlaceholderPosition, respectively. Methods that perform absolute navigation, such as MoveCurrentToPosition, do nothing if the NewItemPlaceholder would be the CurrentItem.

SortDescriptions

Gets a collection of SortDescription structures that describes how the items in the collection are sorted in the view.

public virtual System.ComponentModel.SortDescriptionCollection SortDescriptions { get; }
Value
SortDescriptionCollection

An empty SortDescriptionCollection in all cases.

Remarks

You cannot add a SortDescription to the returned (empty) collection because the base class CollectionView does not support sorting. Instead, use the derived classes ListCollectionView and BindingListCollectionView that do support sorting. Also, check the CanSort property before adding or removing SortDescription objects to avoid an exception.

SourceCollection

Returns the underlying unfiltered collection.

public virtual System.Collections.IEnumerable SourceCollection { get; }
Value
IEnumerable

An IEnumerable object that is the underlying collection.

UpdatedOutsideDispatcher

Gets a value that indicates whether it has been necessary to update the change log because a CollectionChanged notification has been received on a different thread without first entering the user interface (UI) thread dispatcher.

protected bool UpdatedOutsideDispatcher { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if it has been necessary to update the change log because a CollectionChanged notification has been received on a different thread without first entering the user interface (UI) thread dispatcher; otherwise, false.

Methods

ClearChangeLog()

Clears any pending changes from the change log.

protected void ClearChangeLog ();

ClearPendingChanges()

Clears unprocessed changed to the collection.

protected void ClearPendingChanges ();

Contains(Object)

Returns a value that indicates whether the specified item belongs to the view.

public virtual bool Contains (object item);
item
Object

The object to check.

Returns
Boolean

true if the item belongs to the view; otherwise, false.

Remarks

This method does not make any assumptions about whether the item belongs to the underlying collection. If the caller knows that the item belongs to the underlying collection, it is more efficient to call the PassesFilter method.

DeferRefresh()

Enters a defer cycle that you can use to merge changes to the view and delay automatic refresh.

public virtual IDisposable DeferRefresh ();
Returns
IDisposable

An IDisposable object that you can use to dispose of the calling object.

Remarks

The typical usage is to create a using scope with this method and then place multiple view-changing calls within the scope. This delays automatic refresh until the defer cycle is exited.

DetachFromSourceCollection()

Removes the reference to the underlying collection from the CollectionView.

public virtual void DetachFromSourceCollection ();

Remarks

Use this method to unsubscribe to events on the underlying collection and allow the CollectionView to be garbage collected.

GetEnumerator()

Returns an object that you can use to enumerate the items in the view.

protected virtual System.Collections.IEnumerator GetEnumerator ();
Returns
IEnumerator

An IEnumerator object that you can use to enumerate the items in the view.

GetItemAt(Int32)

Retrieves the item at the specified zero-based index in the view.

public virtual object GetItemAt (int index);
index
Int32

The zero-based index of the item to retrieve.

Returns
Object

The item at the specified zero-based index in the view.

Exceptions
ArgumentOutOfRangeException

index is less than 0.

Remarks

This method evaluates the index with any SortDescriptions or Filter property values that are set on the view.

If the underlying collection is of type IEnumerable, this is an O(N) operation.

IndexOf(Object)

Returns the index at which the specified item is located.

public virtual int IndexOf (object item);
item
Object

The item to locate.

Returns
Int32

The index at which the specified item is located, or –1 if the item is unknown.

Remarks

If this method returns an index other than -1, it must always be true that view[index-1] < item <= view[index], where the comparisons are done using the Compare method of the view, if one exists.

This particular behavior of the method is used by some CollectionChanged event handlers to speed up reaction to insertion and deletion. If the derived class does not override this method, a listener does a binary search using the Compare method.

MoveCurrentTo(Object)

Sets the specified item to be the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* in the view.

public virtual bool MoveCurrentTo (object item);
item
Object

The item to set as the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem*.

Returns
Boolean

true if the resulting stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* is within the view; otherwise, false.

Remarks

If the specified item is not found, the method returns false and the CurrentItem is positioned before the beginning of the collection in the view.

Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer. As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection. For more information, see "Binding to Collections" in Data Binding Overview.

For more information about the current item of a view, see CurrentItem.

MoveCurrentToFirst()

Sets the first item in the view as the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem*.

public virtual bool MoveCurrentToFirst ();
Returns
Boolean

true if the resulting stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* is an item within the view; otherwise, false.

Remarks

Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer. As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection. For more information, see "Binding to Collections" in Data Binding Overview.

MoveCurrentToLast()

Sets the last item in the view as the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem*.

public virtual bool MoveCurrentToLast ();
Returns
Boolean

true if the resulting stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* is an item within the view; otherwise, false.

Remarks

Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer. As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection. For more information, see "Binding to Collections" in Data Binding Overview.

MoveCurrentToNext()

Sets the item after the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* in the view as the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem*.

public virtual bool MoveCurrentToNext ();
Returns
Boolean

true if the resulting stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* is an item within the view; otherwise, false.

Remarks

Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer. As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection. For more information, see "Binding to Collections" in Data Binding Overview.

MoveCurrentToPosition(Int32)

Sets the item at the specified index to be the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* in the view.

public virtual bool MoveCurrentToPosition (int position);
position
Int32

The index to set the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* to.

Returns
Boolean

true if the resulting stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* is an item within the view; otherwise, false.

Remarks

Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer. As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection. For more information, see "Binding to Collections" in Data Binding Overview.

MoveCurrentToPrevious()

Sets the item before the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* in the view as the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem*.

public virtual bool MoveCurrentToPrevious ();
Returns
Boolean

true if the resulting stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* is an item within the view; otherwise, false.

Remarks

Collection views support the concept of a current record pointer. As you navigate through the objects in a collection view, you are moving a record pointer that allows you to retrieve the object that exists at that particular location in the collection. For more information, see "Binding to Collections" in Data Binding Overview.

OKToChangeCurrent()

Returns a value that indicates whether the view can change which item is the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem*.

protected bool OKToChangeCurrent ();
Returns
Boolean

false if a listener cancels the change; otherwise, true.

OnAllowsCrossThreadChangesChanged()

Occurs when the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.AllowsCrossThreadChanges* property changes.

protected virtual void OnAllowsCrossThreadChangesChanged ();

OnBeginChangeLogging(NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs)

Called by the base class to notify the derived class that an CollectionChanged event has been posted to the message queue.

protected virtual void OnBeginChangeLogging (System.Collections.Specialized.NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs args);
args
NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs

The NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs object that is added to the change log.

Exceptions
ArgumentNullException

args is null.

OnCollectionChanged(NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs)

Raises the CollectionChanged event.

protected virtual void OnCollectionChanged (System.Collections.Specialized.NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs args);
args
NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs

The NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs object to pass to the event handler.

Remarks

Take any sorting, filtering, or grouping criteria into consideration before calling this method to raise the CollectionChanged event.

OnCollectionChanged(Object,NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs)

Raises the CollectionChanged event.

protected void OnCollectionChanged (object sender, System.Collections.Specialized.NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs args);
sender
Object

The sender of the event.

args
NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs

The NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs object to pass to the event handler.

Remarks

This method calls ProcessCollectionChanged if it is on the correct UI thread dispatcher and has never been updated from a different thread, or posts the change to the dispatcher to process it on the correct thread.

OnCurrentChanged()

Raises the CurrentChanged event.

protected virtual void OnCurrentChanged ();

OnCurrentChanging()

Raises a CurrentChanging event that is not cancelable.

protected void OnCurrentChanging ();

Remarks

This method sets CurrentPosition to –1. This method is called by collection changes that affect the CurrentItem.

OnCurrentChanging(CurrentChangingEventArgs)

Raises the CurrentChanging event with the specified arguments.

protected virtual void OnCurrentChanging (System.ComponentModel.CurrentChangingEventArgs args);
args
CurrentChangingEventArgs

Information about the event.

OnPropertyChanged(PropertyChangedEventArgs)

Raises the PropertyChanged event using the specified arguments.

protected virtual void OnPropertyChanged (System.ComponentModel.PropertyChangedEventArgs e);
e
PropertyChangedEventArgs

Arguments of the event being raised.

PassesFilter(Object)

Returns a value that indicates whether the specified item in the underlying collection belongs to the view.

public virtual bool PassesFilter (object item);
item
Object

The item to check.

Returns
Boolean

true if the specified item belongs to the view or if there is not filter set on the collection view; otherwise, false.

Remarks

Unlike the Contains method, this method assumes that the specified item belongs to the underlying collection. This method takes filters into account. Typically, you use this method during collection-changed notifications to determine if the added or removed item requires processing.

ProcessCollectionChanged(NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs)

When overridden in a derived class, processes a single change on the UI thread.

protected virtual void ProcessCollectionChanged (System.Collections.Specialized.NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs args);
args
NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs

The NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs object to process.

ProcessPendingChanges()

Ensures that all pending changes to the collection have been committed.

protected void ProcessPendingChanges ();

Refresh()

Re-creates the view.

public virtual void Refresh ();

Remarks

When you set the Filter, SortDescriptions, or GroupDescriptions property; a refresh occurs. You do not have to call the Refresh method immediately after you set one of those properties. For information about how to delay automatic refresh, see DeferRefresh.

Derived classes use the protected RefreshOverride method to override the behavior of this method.

RefreshOrDefer()

Refreshes the view or specifies that the view needs to be refreshed when the defer cycle completes.

protected void RefreshOrDefer ();

RefreshOverride()

Re-creates the view.

protected virtual void RefreshOverride ();

SetCurrent(Object,Int32)

Sets the specified item and index as the values of the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* and stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentPosition* properties.

protected void SetCurrent (object newItem, int newPosition);
newItem
Object

The item to set as the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem*.

newPosition
Int32

The value to set as the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentPosition* property value.

SetCurrent(Object,Int32,Int32)

Sets the specified item and index as the values of the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* and stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentPosition* properties. This method can be called from a constructor of a derived class.

protected void SetCurrent (object newItem, int newPosition, int count);
newItem
Object

The item to set as the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem*.

newPosition
Int32

The value to set as the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentPosition* property value.

count
Int32

The number of items in the CollectionView.

Remarks

Call this overload from constructor of a derived class. Do not pass the Count property, which is a virtual property, as count. Instead, pass the count of the internal IList that represents the collection.

SetCurrent is introduced in the .NET Framework version 3.5. For more information, see Versions and Dependencies.

Events

CollectionChanged

Occurs when the view has changed.

protected virtual event System.Collections.Specialized.NotifyCollectionChangedEventHandler CollectionChanged;

CurrentChanged

Occurs after the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* has changed.

public virtual event EventHandler CurrentChanged;

CurrentChanging

Occurs when the stem.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem* is changing.

public virtual event System.ComponentModel.CurrentChangingEventHandler CurrentChanging;

PropertyChanged

Occurs when a property value has changed.

protected virtual event System.ComponentModel.PropertyChangedEventHandler PropertyChanged;

Explicit Interface Implementations

IEnumerable.GetEnumerator()

Returns an IEnumerator object that you can use to enumerate the items in the view.

System.Collections.IEnumerator IEnumerable.GetEnumerator ();
Returns
IEnumerator

An IEnumerator object that you can use to enumerate the items in the view.
